I'm sorry you're having so much trouble.  UNIX can be complicated :)

> b) When launching Eclipse from a shortcut on the desktop EVEN if the
> /etc/bash.bashrc file has the correct MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME set (confirmed through
> shells) the IDE wont see it.

When you run a shortcut on the desktop, its environment is inherited from the
process that started the desktop session (gnome-session, kdeinit, etc).  Any
changes to /etc/bash.bashrc require this process be restarted, and depend on
that process being spawned from a bash session. If you're still unsure about
what's going on, ask your distribution or someone from GNOME or KDE what the
right place is to change the environment for launched applications.

When you start a bash process in a shell, it will obviously get its environment
from /etc/bash.bashrc

> c) Unfortunately, even setting a MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME environment variable in the
> Run.. launcher settings (append has no effect - the blank screen situation)

Try also setting LD_LIBRARY_PATH.  When you run a launch config, Eclipse
executes "java" directly and does not use the eclipse launcher.  The eclipse
launcher is the executable sets LD_LIBRARY_PATH to include whatever is in your
MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME.  This won't be done if you use a launch config.

> replace causes a SWT error [...]
> org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more handles [gtk_init_check() failed]

When you replace the environment, you replace all variables, including DISPLAY.
GTK+ is failing because it can't open your X display.


To answer your concern about environment tweaking, there is a standard for how
to find an embeddable Mozilla, and it's the "gre.conf" configuration file which
is read by the eclipse launcher executable. The work now is to ensure that all
of the distributions ship it and point it at an embeddable Mozilla. It's
unfortunate that Mozilla doesn't provide good documentation for this, but
regardless please file bugs like the Ubuntu one I linked to above.
